description:
Sinocyclocheilus rhinocerous is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the genus Sinocyclocheilus, which is a genus of fish in the family Cyprinidae. The species is found in China, specifically in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region.

Sinocyclocheilus rhinocerous is a small-sized fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 12 centimeters (4.7 inches). It is characterized by its distinctive features, including a prominent, horn-like protrusion on its head, which is the source of its common name "rhinoceros carp." This unique feature is believed to be an adaptation that helps the fish navigate and navigate through the complex, rocky habitats it inhabits.

The species is generally found in fast-flowing streams and rivers with rocky substrates. It is known to feed primarily on algae and aquatic plants, using its specialized mouth and dentition to graze on these food sources.

Sinocyclocheilus rhinocerous is considered a vulnerable species due to factors such as habitat degradation, pollution, and overexploitation. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this unique and fascinating fish species.
